Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Computational Physics for Research and Industry
Award.AbstractNarration:
The principal investigator (PI) intends to apply his expertise in computational fluid dynamics, space science, and plasma physics, to construct an integrated teaching and research program in computational physics. This project will address the needs of the Huntsville area for an experienced technical workforce by developing a unique educational resource within the Department of Physics at the University of Alabama in Huntsville (UAH), with support from the UAH Center for Space Plasma and Aeronomic Research (CSPAR). The PI's team includes thirteen new faculty members and researchers recently hired by UAH Physics and CSPAR, all of whom are closely involved in computational science research.

The PI plans to create a new track in Computational Physics as part of the UAH Master's degree program in the Department of Physics. This curriculum will serve both prospective students and local industry by providing advance training in numerical and supercomputer techniques. The project's research component will include the development of a comprehensive computer model of the Solar System, from Earth to its outer edge and into the surrounding interstellar cloud. This model will address science problems in charged particle acceleration, pickup ions and neutral atoms, the physics of interplanetary turbulence, the transport of cosmic rays, and solar wind interaction with the interstellar medium. In addition, the PI will develop new supercomputing technologies, including graphic processor-based computing, using UAH's existing 400-core computing cluster, and eventually larger supercomputer resources expected to be available in the future.

The two main objectives of this sponsored project were to introduce and support a graduate (Master's and Doctoral) curriculum in Computational Physics and to develop and maintain, in parallel, a research program in computational space physics. The UAH Space Science Department, where the PI of this project is employed, has emerged as a regional leader in computational science research and education. Modern research in any STEM field is inconceivable without a knowledge of computational methods. The program prepares future scientists for the realities and demands of modern computational environment. The curriculum was developed with input from the Huntsville area science and technology business community.

The curriculum consists of four graduate courses taught every year or biennially. These courses had no predecessors and were developed from the ground up. Between 2011 and 2016 the Department has taught the following:

  • Computational Physics ­ (introductionry broad reaching course) - 5 times (2011, 2012, 2013, 2014, 2016);
  • Computational Fluid Dynamics and MHD ­ (specialized for those interested in numerical gas-, fluid-, and plasma-dynamics) - 2 times (2013, 2015);
  • Stochastic Methods of Computational Physics ­ (broad applications from physics and biology to finance) - 1 time (2014);
  • Computational Plasma Physics ­ (specialized for those interested in space and laboratory plasmas) - 1 time (2015).

The computational physics curriculum became one of the major attractions of the new graduate program in Space Science, also developed by the PI. It has, in addition to Space Science graduate students, served students from the departments of Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering and Physics, which demonstrates its general appeal among science and engineering students. A total of 40 students have enrolled in the various courses since the progran's inception.

The project supported the research of two graduate students and a postdoctoral researcher. This work generated many significant scientific results that were published and presented at scientific meetings. In numbers, 23 journal papers were published reporting work that was supported, wholly or partially, by this grant. Nearly 30 presentations were made at different conferences to disseminate the findings to the professional community. Most of our science is connected to the NASA's Voyager interstellar mission. Launched in 1977, the twin Voyager space probes are the farthest traveled man made objects, with Voyager 1 currently 20 billion km away from Eartrh. Our research focused on explaining, using computer models, the puzzling observations of the rarefied magnetized plasma that comprizes much of the volume of the Milky Way galaxy. Some of our more significant findings are:

  • Our models yielded a definitive answer to the problem of modulation of cosmic rays beyond the boundary of the solar system (known as the heliopause).
